STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 29, 2022
Trisha Sverns
Samaritas - West
2080 Union Ave.SE Suite A
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
RE: License #: CB410201266
Samaritas - West
2080 Union Ave.SE Suite A
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
Dear Ms. Sverns:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 26, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (231) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Name: Samaritas

2080 Union Ave. SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507

Name of Facility: Samaritas - West

Grand Rapids, MI 49507

SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
Two of sixteen employee files reviewed did not contain documentation that three
references were obtained prior to hire as required.
File one: Date of hire was 11/12/2021; one reference dated 11/12/2021 and another
reference dated 11/14/2021.
File two: Date of hire was 1/18/2022; two references dated 1/20/2022 and one
reference dated 1/21/2022.
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i)The Michigan state police of the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
One of sixteen employee files reviewed contained documentation that criminal
background clearances were not obtained prior to hire as required.
File one: Date of hire was 1/18/2022 and criminal background clearance was
completed on 1/25/2022.
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
4

Three of sixteen employee files reviewed contained documentation that Central
Registry (CR) clearances were not obtained prior to hire as required.
File one: Date of hire was 7/5/2022; Michigan CR clearance obtained 7/10/2022 and
Colorado CR clearance obtained 7/15/2022.
File two: Date of hire was 3/14/2022; Virginia CR clearance obtained 3/25/2022.
File three: Date of hire was 1/18/2022; Michigan CR clearance obtained 2/1/2022 and
Arizona CR clearance obtained 1/24/2022.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department’s
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not submit a special investigation
record to the department’s licensing authority within 5 working days as required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report required
by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 calendar days of completion as
required.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
Three of four open independent living files reviewed did not contain the
responsibilities of the agency as the 1297 does not include this information.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed
and updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
5

Three of four open independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation
the independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth every 90 days
as required.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the
child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory oversight
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed did have documented monthly
supervision with staff as required.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
6

FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Two of four independent living files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the
case service plan within 14 days as required.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Six of eight foster care files and 4 of 4 independent living files reviewed did not
contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
File one: 5/26/2022 PATP mother signature not timely (8/16/2022) and father's refusal
is not dated.
File two: 10/26/2021 PATP: father’s not provided timely (12/3/2021), FP signature not
timely (12/2/2021); 1/11/2022 PATP: FP signature not obtained timely. SWC dated
2/9/2022 states they signed but date on uploaded PATP is 3/18, unable to read
mother’s signature and date (2/9/2022 SWC indicates she signed then); 4/5/2022
PATP: mother signature not timely (5/17/2022), FP signature not timely (5/6/2022),
and father’s not emailed timely (5/20/2022).
File three: 2/17/2022 PATP-FP signature not obtained timely (6/2/2022).
File four: 12/3/2021 and 3/3/2022 PATP: FP signature not obtained timely
(5/19/2022).
File five: 12/320/21 PATP-FP signature not timely (1/25/2022); 5/23/2022 PATP-
relative caregiver signature not obtained timely (8/24/2022)
File six: 4/13/2022 PATP-mother signature not timely (6/29/2022).
File seven: 11/16/2021 and 2/14/2022 PATP are signed but not dated, 5/12/2022
signature not obtained timely (8/12/2022).
File eight: 5/18/2022 PATP signature not obtained timely (6/23/2022).
File nine: 2/3/2022 PATP signature not obtained timely (3/22/2022), 6/13/2022 PATP
signature not obtained timely (7/19/2022).
File ten: 11/18/2021 PATP does not have a signature uploaded, 6/28/2022 PATP is
not uploaded so unable to verify signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/10/2021
8/10/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/17/2020
7

FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile
Justice Action Summary and upload to MISACWIS within the
timeframe required for the specified action/change.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS-69 Action Summary
forms completed for placement changes as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/10/2021 (cited under FOM 722-15)
8/10/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/17/2020
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include reunification,
placement in a residential setting, step-down from a residential or
hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in
foster home/relative placements.
8

Three of eight foster care files and 1 of 4 independent living files reviewed did not
have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: There is no corresponding FTM for 5/3/2022 and 5/26/2022 placement
changes.
File two: There is no corresponding FTM for 4/5/2022 USP. USP documents it was
cancelled due to mother requesting her attorney be present but was not rescheduled.
File three: There is no corresponding FTM for 4/13/2022 ISP (4/19/2022 FTM is not
able to be counted); there is no FTM documented for 3/22/2022 and 3/23/2022
placement changes.
File four: There is no corresponding FTM for 2/14/2022 USP (1/10/2022 FTM is too
early to be counted).
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Three of eight foster care files and 3 of 4 independent living files reviewed contained
FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven
business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/10/2021
8/10/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/17/2020
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
 All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
9

services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
 Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Two of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
File one: Initial medical passport not provided within 14 days of removal. Child was
removed on 4/27/2022 and initial medical passport in MISACWIS was dated
7/21/2022.
File two: There are no medical passports between 7/24/2021-7/18/2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/10/2021
8/10/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/17/2020
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Note on PATP signature line if worker virtually reviewed with parent or foster
parent, PATP was mailed or emailed, or parent refused to sign.
 Consider adding an HR form that asks applicant if they have resided or
attended school in another state within the last 5 years.
 Reference forms need to be dated.
 The DHS 1297 YAVFC Agreement does not substitute the required IL
contract as it does not include all the required information per the rules. If this
form is to be used, the agency needs to add what the agency responsibilities
are in order to be in compliance with licensing rules.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation.
10

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
The agency has submitted four acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2022C0112005 was initiated on 1/13/2022 regarding allegations a staff member
took a youth to the store and attempted to hug youth and touch his penis. There was
not enough evidence to support the allegations of sexual advances. However, a
violation was determined for rule R 400.12206(1) staff qualifications due to staff
admitting to taking youth to the store and smoking with youth while in the vehicle. A
CAP was approved on 5/4/2022 and continues to be implemented at this time.
SIR 2022C0212011 was initiated on 3/21/2022 due to allegations the agency did not
provide known information to foster parents regarding an aggressive and assaultive
youth. There was no evidence to support this allegation as the agency verbally
provided this information to the foster parents. However, during the course of the
investigation it was determined this information was not provided to the foster
parents in writing as required in rule R 400.12405 change of placement. A CAP was
approved on 6/14/2022 and continues to be implemented at this time.
SIR 2022C0444018 was initiated on 7/12/2022 due to allegations the agency was
not utilizing interpreter services for a foster child who is deaf. The investigation
determined the agency was not utilizing interpreter services during all of the foster
home visits with the youth despite documentation in the case indicating youth uses
American Sign Language in order to communicate. A CAP was submitted and is
pending approval.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
interim inspection completed on 9/27/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
11/10/2021. During the review the agency had seven violations. Four citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency noted that staff turnover and retention impacted overall compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during this
review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the previous year CAP was
effective and the agency conducts internal file audits to achieve compliance. The CA
noted the file audits have been particularly effective with medical and dental
requirements. However, the agency has struggled with turnover, and it has impacted
compliance overall.
The CA indicated that the agency has seen good results by pairing new staff with
mentors right away. In addition, the agency has implemented protected time for staff,
11

updated checklists and in-services. The CA noted the agency has an internal quality
process called QAPI that they utilize as well as quarterly performance reports. The
CA expressed confidence that several areas will improve over the next review period.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with four staff via telephone. Staff acknowledge this year
has been somewhat challenging due to high turnover. However, they felt confident
the agency was taking the appropriate steps to address staffing issues. Staff reported
supervisors were available when needed and felt supported. Staff did not report any
areas of need.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
____________8/26/2022__________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 26, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
12
